member.name: T:SharpFont.AutoHinterScript
member.summary: A list of constants used for the glyph-to-script-map property to specify the script submodule the auto-hinter should use for hinting a particular glyph.

member.name: F:SharpFont.AutoHinterScript.None
member.summary: Don't auto-hint this glyph.

member.name: F:SharpFont.AutoHinterScript.Latin
member.summary: Apply the latin auto-hinter. For the auto-hinter, ‘latin’ is a very broad term, including Cyrillic and Greek also since characters from those scripts share the same design constraints.

remarks.para: By default, characters from the following Unicode ranges are assigned to this submodule.

para.code: U+0020 - U+007F // Basic Latin (no control characters) U+00A0 - U+00FF // Latin-1 Supplement (no control characters) U+0100 - U+017F // Latin Extended-A U+0180 - U+024F // Latin Extended-B U+0250 - U+02AF // IPA Extensions U+02B0 - U+02FF // Spacing Modifier Letters U+0300 - U+036F // Combining Diacritical Marks U+0370 - U+03FF // Greek and Coptic U+0400 - U+04FF // Cyrillic U+0500 - U+052F // Cyrillic Supplement U+1D00 - U+1D7F // Phonetic Extensions U+1D80 - U+1DBF // Phonetic Extensions Supplement U+1DC0 - U+1DFF // Combining Diacritical Marks Supplement U+1E00 - U+1EFF // Latin Extended Additional U+1F00 - U+1FFF // Greek Extended U+2000 - U+206F // General Punctuation U+2070 - U+209F // Superscripts and Subscripts U+20A0 - U+20CF // Currency Symbols U+2150 - U+218F // Number Forms U+2460 - U+24FF // Enclosed Alphanumerics U+2C60 - U+2C7F // Latin Extended-C U+2DE0 - U+2DFF // Cyrillic Extended-A U+2E00 - U+2E7F // Supplemental Punctuation U+A640 - U+A69F // Cyrillic Extended-B U+A720 - U+A7FF // Latin Extended-D U+FB00 - U+FB06 // Alphab. Present. Forms (Latin Ligatures) U+1D400 - U+1D7FF // Mathematical Alphanumeric Symbols U+1F100 - U+1F1FF // Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement

member.name: F:SharpFont.AutoHinterScript.Cjk
member.summary: Apply the CJK auto-hinter, covering Chinese, Japanese, Korean, old Vietnamese, and some other scripts.

remarks.para: By default, characters from the following Unicode ranges are assigned to this submodule.

para.code: U+1100 - U+11FF // Hangul Jamo U+2E80 - U+2EFF // CJK Radicals Supplement U+2F00 - U+2FDF // Kangxi Radicals U+2FF0 - U+2FFF // Ideographic Description Characters U+3000 - U+303F // CJK Symbols and Punctuation U+3040 - U+309F // Hiragana U+30A0 - U+30FF // Katakana U+3100 - U+312F // Bopomofo U+3130 - U+318F // Hangul Compatibility Jamo U+3190 - U+319F // Kanbun U+31A0 - U+31BF // Bopomofo Extended U+31C0 - U+31EF // CJK Strokes U+31F0 - U+31FF // Katakana Phonetic Extensions U+3200 - U+32FF // Enclosed CJK Letters and Months U+3300 - U+33FF // CJK Compatibility U+3400 - U+4DBF // CJK Unified Ideographs Extension A U+4DC0 - U+4DFF // Yijing Hexagram Symbols U+4E00 - U+9FFF // CJK Unified Ideographs U+A960 - U+A97F // Hangul Jamo Extended-A U+AC00 - U+D7AF // Hangul Syllables U+D7B0 - U+D7FF // Hangul Jamo Extended-B U+F900 - U+FAFF // CJK Compatibility Ideographs U+FE10 - U+FE1F // Vertical forms U+FE30 - U+FE4F // CJK Compatibility Forms U+FF00 - U+FFEF // Halfwidth and Fullwidth Forms U+1B000 - U+1B0FF // Kana Supplement U+1D300 - U+1D35F // Tai Xuan Hing Symbols U+1F200 - U+1F2FF // Enclosed Ideographic Supplement U+20000 - U+2A6DF // CJK Unified Ideographs Extension B U+2A700 - U+2B73F // CJK Unified Ideographs Extension C U+2B740 - U+2B81F // CJK Unified Ideographs Extension D U+2F800 - U+2FA1F // CJK Compatibility Ideographs Supplement

member.name: F:SharpFont.AutoHinterScript.Indic
member.summary: Apply the indic auto-hinter, covering all major scripts from the Indian sub-continent and some other related scripts like Thai, Lao, or Tibetan.

remarks.para: By default, characters from the following Unicode ranges are assigned to this submodule.

para.code: U+0900 - U+0DFF // Indic Range U+0F00 - U+0FFF // Tibetan U+1900 - U+194F // Limbu U+1B80 - U+1BBF // Sundanese U+1C80 - U+1CDF // Meetei Mayak U+A800 - U+A82F // Syloti Nagri U+11800 - U+118DF // Sharada

remarks.para: Note that currently Indic support is rudimentary only, missing blue zone support.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16.MultiplyFix(System.Int32,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)
member.summary: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*b)/0x10000’ with maximal accuracy. Most of the time this is used to multiply a given value by a 16.16 fixed float factor.

remarks.para: NOTE: This is a native FreeType function.

This function has been optimized for the case where the absolute value of ‘a’ is less than 2048, and ‘b’ is a 16.16 scaling factor. As this happens mainly when scaling from notional units to fractional pixels in FreeType, it resulted in noticeable speed improvements between versions 2.x and 1.x.
As a conclusion, always try to place a 16.16 factor as the second argument of this function; this can make a great difference.

member.param: The second multiplier. Use a 16.16 factor here whenever possible (see note below).

member.name: M:SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16.Divide(SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)
member.summary: Divides one 16.16 values from another.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16.DivideFix(System.Int32,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)
member.summary: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*0x10000)/b’ with maximal accuracy. Most of the time, this is used to divide a given value by a 16.16 fixed float factor.

remarks.para: NOTE: This is a native FreeType function.
The optimization for is simple: If (a << 16) fits in 32 bits, then the division is computed directly. Otherwise, we use a specialized version of .

member.param: The second multiplier. Use a 16.16 factor here whenever possible (see note below).

member.name: M:SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16.MultiplyDivide(SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)

summary.para: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*b)/c’ with maximal accuracy (it uses a 64-bit intermediate integer whenever necessary).
This function isn't necessarily as fast as some processor specific operations, but is at least completely portable.

member.remarks: This is a native FreeType function.
member.returns: The result of ‘(a*b)/c’. This function never traps when trying to divide by zero; it simply returns ‘MaxInt’ or ‘MinInt’ depending on the signs of ‘a’ and ‘b’.

member.summary: Return the arc-tangent corresponding to a given vector (x,y) in the 2d plane.
member.remarks: This is a native FreeType function.

member.summary: Return the difference between two angles. The result is always constrained to the [-PI..PI] interval.
member.remarks: This is a native FreeType function.

member.name: T:SharpFont.FTBitmap
member.summary: A structure used to describe a bitmap or pixmap to the raster. Note that we now manage pixmaps of various depths through the field.
member.remarks: For now, the only pixel modes supported by FreeType are mono and grays. However, drivers might be added in the future to support more ‘colorful’ options.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Gets the number of bitmap rows.

member.name: P:SharpFont.FTBitmap.Width
member.summary: Gets the number of pixels in bitmap row.

summary.para: Gets the pitch's absolute value is the number of bytes taken by one bitmap row, including padding. However, the pitch is positive when the bitmap has a ‘down’ flow, and negative when it has an ‘up’ flow. In all cases, the pitch is an offset to add to a bitmap pointer in order to go down one row.
Note that ‘padding’ means the alignment of a bitmap to a byte border, and FreeType functions normally align to the smallest possible integer value.
For the B/W rasterizer, ‘pitch’ is always an even number.

To change the pitch of a bitmap (say, to make it a multiple of 4), use . Alternatively, you might use callback functions to directly render to the application's surface; see the file ‘example2.cpp’ in the tutorial for a demonstration.

member.summary: Gets how the palette is stored. This field is intended for paletted pixel modes.

member.name: M:SharpFont.FTBitmap.Embolden(SharpFont.Library,SharpFont.Fixed26Dot6,SharpFont.Fixed26Dot6)
member.summary: Embolden a bitmap. The new bitmap will be about ‘xStrength’ pixels wider and ‘yStrength’ pixels higher. The left and bottom borders are kept unchanged.

remarks.para: The current implementation restricts ‘xStrength’ to be less than or equal to 8 if bitmap is of pixel_mode .
If you want to embolden the bitmap owned by a , you should call on the slot first.

member.param: A handle to a library object.
How strong the glyph is emboldened horizontally. Expressed in 26.6 pixel format.
How strong the glyph is emboldened vertically. Expressed in 26.6 pixel format.

member.name: M:SharpFont.FTBitmap.Convert(SharpFont.Library,System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert a bitmap object with depth 1bpp, 2bpp, 4bpp, or 8bpp to a bitmap object with depth 8bpp, making the number of used bytes per line (a.k.a. the ‘pitch’) a multiple of ‘alignment’.

remarks.para: It is possible to call multiple times without calling (the memory is simply reallocated).
Use to finally remove the bitmap object.
The ‘library’ argument is taken to have access to FreeType's memory handling functions.

member.param: A handle to a library object.
The pitch of the bitmap is a multiple of this parameter. Common values are 1, 2, or 4.

member.name: T:SharpFont.BitmapSize
member.summary: This structure models the metrics of a bitmap strike (i.e., a set of glyphs for a given point size and resolution) in a bitmap font. It is used for the field of .

remarks.para: Windows FNT: The nominal size given in a FNT font is not reliable. Thus when the driver finds it incorrect, it sets ‘size’ to some calculated values and sets ‘x_ppem’ and ‘y_ppem’ to the pixel width and height given in the font, respectively.
TrueType embedded bitmaps: ‘size’, ‘width’, and ‘height’ values are not contained in the bitmap strike itself. They are computed from the global font parameters.

member.summary: Gets the vertical distance, in pixels, between two consecutive baselines. It is always positive.

member.name: P:SharpFont.BitmapSize.Width
member.summary: Gets the average width, in pixels, of all glyphs in the strike.

member.summary: Gets the nominal size of the strike in 26.6 fractional points. This field is not very useful.

member.summary: Gets the horizontal ppem (nominal width) in 26.6 fractional pixels.

member.name: P:SharpFont.BitmapSize.NominalHeight
member.summary: Gets the vertical ppem (nominal height) in 26.6 fractional pixels.

member.param: The parent manager for the image cache.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.ImageCache.Lookup(SharpFont.Cache.ImageType,System.UInt32,SharpFont.Cache.Node@)
member.summary: Retrieve a given glyph image from a glyph image cache.

remarks.para: The returned glyph is owned and managed by the glyph image cache. Never try to transform or discard it manually! You can however create a copy with and modify the new one.

If ‘node’ is not NULL, it receives the address of the cache node containing the glyph image, after increasing its reference count. This ensures that the node (as well as the ) will always be kept in the cache until you call to ‘release’ it.
If ‘node’ is NULL, the cache node is left unchanged, which means that the could be flushed out of the cache on the next call to one of the caching sub-system APIs. Don't assume that it is persistent!

member.param: A pointer to a glyph image type descriptor.
Used to return the address of of the corresponding cache node after incrementing its reference count (see note below).
member.returns: The corresponding object. 0 in case of failure.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.ImageCache.LookupScaler(SharpFont.Cache.Scaler,SharpFont.LoadFlags,System.UInt32,SharpFont.Cache.Node@)
member.summary: A variant of that uses a to specify the face ID and its size.

remarks.para: The returned glyph is owned and managed by the glyph image cache. Never try to transform or discard it manually! You can however create a copy with and modify the new one.

If ‘node’ is not NULL, it receives the address of the cache node containing the glyph image, after increasing its reference count. This ensures that the node (as well as the ) will always be kept in the cache until you call to ‘release’ it.
If ‘node’ is NULL, the cache node is left unchanged, which means that the could be flushed out of the cache on the next call to one of the caching sub-system APIs. Don't assume that it is persistent!
Calls to and friends have no effect on cached glyphs; you should always use the FreeType cache API instead.

member.param: A pointer to a scaler descriptor.
Used to return the address of of the corresponding cache node after incrementing its reference count (see note below).
member.returns: The corresponding object. 0 in case of failure.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Cache.ImageType.Flags
member.summary: Gets the load flags, as in

summary.para: This object corresponds to one instance of the cache-subsystem. It is used to cache one or more objects, along with corresponding objects.
The manager intentionally limits the total number of opened and objects to control memory usage. See the ‘max_faces’ and ‘max_sizes’ parameters of .
The manager is also used to cache ‘nodes’ of various types while limiting their total memory usage.
All limitations are enforced by keeping lists of managed objects in most-recently-used order, and flushing old nodes to make room for new ones.

member.param: The parent FreeType library handle to use.
Maximum number of opened objects managed by this cache instance. Use 0 for defaults.

Maximum number of bytes to use for cached data nodes. Use 0 for defaults. Note that this value does not account for managed and objects.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Manager.Reset
member.summary: Empty a given cache manager. This simply gets rid of all the currently cached and objects within the manager.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Manager.LookupFace(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Retrieve the object that corresponds to a given face ID through a cache manager.

remarks.para: The returned object is always owned by the manager. You should never try to discard it yourself.
The object doesn't necessarily have a current size object (i.e., can be 0). If you need a specific ‘font size’, use instead.
Never change the face's transformation matrix (i.e., never call the function) on a returned face! If you need to transform glyphs, do it yourself after glyph loading.
When you perform a lookup, out-of-memory errors are detected within the lookup and force incremental flushes of the cache until enough memory is released for the lookup to succeed.
If a lookup fails with the cache has already been completely flushed, and still no memory was available for the operation.

member.param: The ID of the face object.
member.returns: A handle to the face object.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Manager.LookupSize(SharpFont.Cache.Scaler)
member.summary: Retrieve the object that corresponds to a given pointer through a cache manager.

remarks.para: The returned object is always owned by the/ manager. You should never try to discard it by yourself.
You can access the parent object simply as if you need it. Note that this object is also owned by the manager.
When you perform a lookup, out-of-memory errors are detected within the lookup and force incremental flushes of the cache until enough memory is released for the lookup to succeed.
If a lookup fails with the cache has already been completely flushed, and still no memory is available for the operation.

member.returns: A handle to the size object.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Manager.RemoveFaceId(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: A special function used to indicate to the cache manager that a given FTC_FaceID is no longer valid, either because its content changed, or because it was deallocated or uninstalled.

remarks.para: This function flushes all nodes from the cache corresponding to this ‘faceID’, with the exception of nodes with a non-null reference count.
Such nodes are however modified internally so as to never appear in later lookups with the same ‘faceID’ value, and to be immediately destroyed when released by all their users.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Manager.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the Manager.

summary.para: An opaque handle to a cache node object. Each cache node is reference-counted. A node with a count of 0 might be flushed out of a full cache whenever a lookup request is performed.

If you look up nodes, you have the ability to ‘acquire’ them, i.e., to increment their reference count. This will prevent the node from being flushed out of the cache until you explicitly ‘release’ it.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.Node.Unref(SharpFont.Cache.Manager)
member.summary: Decrement a cache node's internal reference count. When the count reaches 0, it is not destroyed but becomes eligible for subsequent cache flushes.

member.name: T:SharpFont.Cache.SBitCache
member.summary: A handle to a small bitmap cache. These are special cache objects used to store small glyph bitmaps (and anti-aliased pixmaps) in a much more efficient way than the traditional glyph image cache implemented by .

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.SBitCache.#ctor(SharpFont.Cache.Manager)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A handle to the source cache manager.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.SBitCache.Lookup(SharpFont.Cache.ImageType,System.UInt32,SharpFont.Cache.Node@)
member.summary: Look up a given small glyph bitmap in a given sbit cache and ‘lock’ it to prevent its flushing from the cache until needed.

remarks.para: The small bitmap descriptor and its bit buffer are owned by the cache and should never be freed by the application. They might as well disappear from memory on the next cache lookup, so don't treat them as persistent data.
The descriptor's ‘buffer’ field is set to 0 to indicate a missing glyph bitmap.

If ‘node’ is not NULL, it receives the address of the cache node containing the bitmap, after increasing its reference count. This ensures that the node (as well as the image) will always be kept in the cache until you call to ‘release’ it.

If ‘node’ is NULL, the cache node is left unchanged, which means that the bitmap could be flushed out of the cache on the next call to one of the caching sub-system APIs. Don't assume that it is persistent!

member.param: A pointer to the glyph image type descriptor.
Used to return the address of of the corresponding cache node after incrementing its reference count (see note below).
member.returns: A handle to a small bitmap descriptor.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Cache.SBitCache.LookupScaler(SharpFont.Cache.Scaler,SharpFont.LoadFlags,System.UInt32,SharpFont.Cache.Node@)
member.summary: A variant of that uses a to specify the face ID and its size.

remarks.para: The small bitmap descriptor and its bit buffer are owned by the cache and should never be freed by the application. They might as well disappear from memory on the next cache lookup, so don't treat them as persistent data.
The descriptor's ‘buffer’ field is set to 0 to indicate a missing glyph bitmap.

If ‘node’ is not NULL, it receives the address of the cache node containing the bitmap, after increasing its reference count. This ensures that the node (as well as the image) will always be kept in the cache until you call to ‘release’ it.

If ‘node’ is NULL, the cache node is left unchanged, which means that the bitmap could be flushed out of the cache on the next call to one of the caching sub-system APIs. Don't assume that it is persistent!

member.param: A pointer to the scaler descriptor.
Used to return the address of of the corresponding cache node after incrementing its reference count (see note below).
member.returns: A handle to a small bitmap descriptor.

summary.para: Corresponds to the Unicode character set. This value covers all versions of the Unicode repertoire, including ASCII and Latin-1. Most fonts include a Unicode charmap, but not all of them.
For example, if you want to access Unicode value U+1F028 (and the font contains it), use value 0x1F028 as the input value for FT_Get_Char_Index.

summary.para: From Michael Pöttgen <michael@poettgen.de>: The ‘Windows Font Mapping’ article says that is used for the charset of vector fonts, like ‘modern.fon’, ‘roman.fon’, and ‘script.fon’ on Windows.
The ‘CreateFont’ documentation says: The value specifies a character set that is operating-system dependent.
The ‘IFIMETRICS’ documentation from the ‘Windows Driver Development Kit’ says: This font supports an OEM-specific character set. The OEM character set is system dependent.

In general OEM, as opposed to ANSI (i.e., cp1252), denotes the second default codepage that most international versions of Windows have. It is one of the OEM codepages from , and is used for the ‘DOS boxes’, to support legacy applications. A German Windows version for example usually uses ANSI codepage 1252 and OEM codepage 850.

member.name: T:SharpFont.LcdFilter
member.summary: A list of values to identify various types of LCD filters.

member.name: F:SharpFont.LcdFilter.None
member.summary: Do not perform filtering. When used with subpixel rendering, this results in sometimes severe color fringes.

member.name: F:SharpFont.LcdFilter.Default
member.summary: The default filter reduces color fringes considerably, at the cost of a slight blurriness in the output.

member.name: F:SharpFont.LcdFilter.Light
member.summary: The light filter is a variant that produces less blurriness at the cost of slightly more color fringes than the default one. It might be better, depending on taste, your monitor, or your personal vision.

summary.para: This filter corresponds to the original libXft color filter. It provides high contrast output but can exhibit really bad color fringes if glyphs are not extremely well hinted to the pixel grid. In other words, it only works well if the TrueType bytecode interpreter is enabled and high-quality hinted fonts are used.
This filter is only provided for comparison purposes, and might be disabled or stay unsupported in the future.

summary.para: A list of values used to describe an outline's contour orientation.
The TrueType and PostScript specifications use different conventions to determine whether outline contours should be filled or unfilled.

member.name: F:SharpFont.Orientation.TrueType
member.summary: According to the TrueType specification, clockwise contours must be filled, and counter-clockwise ones must be unfilled.

member.name: F:SharpFont.Orientation.PostScript
member.summary: According to the PostScript specification, counter-clockwise contours must be filled, and clockwise ones must be unfilled.

member.name: F:SharpFont.Orientation.FillRight
member.summary: This is identical to , but is used to remember that in TrueType, everything that is to the right of the drawing direction of a contour must be filled.

member.name: F:SharpFont.Orientation.FillLeft
member.summary: This is identical to , but is used to remember that in PostScript, everything that is to the left of the drawing direction of a contour must be filled.

member.name: F:SharpFont.Orientation.None
member.summary: The orientation cannot be determined. That is, different parts of the glyph have different orientation.

member.name: T:SharpFont.OutlineGlyph
member.summary: A structure used for outline (vectorial) glyph images. This really is a ‘sub-class’ of .

remarks.para: You can typecast an to if you have ‘ == ’. This lets you access the outline's content easily.
As the outline is extracted from a glyph slot, its coordinates are expressed normally in 26.6 pixels, unless the flag was used in or .
The outline's tables are always owned by the object and are destroyed with it.

member.name: F:SharpFont.RasterFlags.AntiAlias
member.summary: This flag is set to indicate that an anti-aliased glyph image should be generated. Otherwise, it will be monochrome (1-bit).

summary.para: This flag is set to indicate direct rendering. In this mode, client applications must provide their own span callback. This lets them directly draw or compose over an existing bitmap. If this bit is not set, the target pixmap's buffer must be zeroed before rendering.
Note that for now, direct rendering is only possible with anti-aliased glyphs.
This flag is only used in direct rendering mode. If set, the output will be clipped to a box specified in the ‘clip_box’ field of the structure.
Note that by default, the glyph bitmap is clipped to the target pixmap, except in direct rendering mode where all spans are generated if no clipping box is set.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterNewFunc
member.summary: A function used to create a new raster object.
member.remarks: The ‘memory’ parameter is a typeless pointer in order to avoid un-wanted dependencies on the rest of the FreeType code. In practice, it is an object, i.e., a handle to the standard FreeType memory allocator. However, this field can be completely ignored by a given raster implementation.
member.param: A handle to the memory allocator.
A handle to the new raster object.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterDoneFunc

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterResetFunc

summary.para: FreeType provides an area of memory called the ‘render pool’, available to all registered rasters. This pool can be freely used during a given scan-conversion but is shared by all rasters. Its content is thus transient.
This function is called each time the render pool changes, or just after a new raster object is created.

member.remarks: Rasters can ignore the render pool and rely on dynamic memory allocation if they want to (a handle to the memory allocator is passed to the raster constructor). However, this is not recommended for efficiency purposes.
member.param: A handle to the new raster object.
The address in memory of the render pool.
The size in bytes of the render pool.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterSetModeFunc
member.summary: This function is a generic facility to change modes or attributes in a given raster. This can be used for debugging purposes, or simply to allow implementation-specific ‘features’ in a given raster module.

A 4-byte tag used to name the mode or property.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterRenderFunc
member.summary: Invoke a given raster to scan-convert a given glyph image into a target bitmap.

remarks.para: The exact format of the source image depends on the raster's glyph format defined in its structure. It can be an or anything else in order to support a large array of glyph formats.
Note also that the render function can fail and return a error code if the raster used does not support direct composition.

XXX: For now, the standard raster doesn't support direct composition but this should change for the final release (see the files ‘demos/src/ftgrays.c’ and ‘demos/src/ftgrays2.c’ for examples of distinct implementations which support direct composition).

member.param: A handle to the raster object.
A pointer to an structure used to store the rendering parameters.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterSpanFunc
member.summary: A function used as a call-back by the anti-aliased renderer in order to let client applications draw themselves the gray pixel spans on each scan line.

remarks.para: This callback allows client applications to directly render the gray spans of the anti-aliased bitmap to any kind of surfaces.
This can be used to write anti-aliased outlines directly to a given background bitmap, and even perform translucency.

Note that the ‘count’ field cannot be greater than a fixed value defined by the ‘FT_MAX_GRAY_SPANS’ configuration macro in ‘ftoption.h’. By default, this value is set to 32, which means that if there are more than 32 spans on a given scanline, the callback is called several times with the same ‘y’ parameter in order to draw all callbacks.
Otherwise, the callback is only called once per scan-line, and only for those scanlines that do have ‘gray’ pixels on them.

member.param: The number of spans to draw on this scanline.
A table of ‘count’ spans to draw on the scanline.
User-supplied data that is passed to the callback.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterBitTestFunc

summary.para: THIS TYPE IS DEPRECATED. DO NOT USE IT.

A function used as a call-back by the monochrome scan-converter to test whether a given target pixel is already set to the drawing ‘color’. These tests are crucial to implement drop-out control per-se the TrueType spec.

member.param: User-supplied data that is passed to the callback.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterBitSetFunc

summary.para: THIS TYPE IS DEPRECATED. DO NOT USE IT.
A function used as a call-back by the monochrome scan-converter to set an individual target pixel. This is crucial to implement drop-out control according to the TrueType specification.

member.param: User-supplied data that is passed to the callback.

member.name: T:SharpFont.RasterParams
member.summary: A structure to hold the arguments used by a raster's render function.

remarks.para: An anti-aliased glyph bitmap is drawn if the bit flag is set in the ‘flags’ field, otherwise a monochrome bitmap is generated.

If the bit flag is set in ‘flags’, the raster will call the ‘gray_spans’ callback to draw gray pixel spans, in the case of an aa glyph bitmap, it will call ‘black_spans’, and ‘bit_test’ and ‘bit_set’ in the case of a monochrome bitmap. This allows direct composition over a pre-existing bitmap through user-provided callbacks to perform the span drawing/composition.
Note that the ‘bit_test’ and ‘bit_set’ callbacks are required when rendering a monochrome bitmap, as they are crucial to implement correct drop-out control as defined in the TrueType specification.

member.summary: A convenience function used to parse a whole outline with the stroker. The resulting outline(s) can be retrieved later by functions like and .

remarks.para: If ‘opened’ is 0 (the default), the outline is treated as a closed path, and the stroker generates two distinct ‘border’ outlines.
If ‘opened’ is 1, the outline is processed as an open path, and the stroker generates a single ‘stroke’ outline.
This function calls automatically.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Stroker.GetBorderCounts(SharpFont.StrokerBorder,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Call this function once you have finished parsing your paths with the stroker. It returns the number of points and contours necessary to export one of the ‘border’ or ‘stroke’ outlines generated by the stroker.

remarks.para: When an outline, or a sub-path, is ‘closed’, the stroker generates two independent ‘border’ outlines, named ‘left’ and ‘right’.
When the outline, or a sub-path, is ‘opened’, the stroker merges the ‘border’ outlines with caps. The ‘left’ border receives all points, while the ‘right’ border becomes empty.
Use the function instead if you want to retrieve the counts associated to both borders.

summary.para: Call this function after to export the corresponding border to your own structure.
Note that this function appends the border points and contours to your outline, but does not try to resize its arrays.

remarks.para: Always call this function after to get sure that there is enough room in your object to receive all new data.
When an outline, or a sub-path, is ‘closed’, the stroker generates two independent ‘border’ outlines, named ‘left’ and ‘right’.
When the outline, or a sub-path, is ‘opened’, the stroker merges the ‘border’ outlines with caps. The ‘left’ border receives all points, while the ‘right’ border becomes empty.
Use the function instead if you want to retrieve all borders at once.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Stroker.GetCounts(System.UInt32@,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Call this function once you have finished parsing your paths with the stroker. It returns the number of points and contours necessary to export all points/borders from the stroked outline/path.

summary.para: Call this function after to export all borders to your own structure.
Note that this function appends the border points and contours to your outline, but does not try to resize its arrays.

member.summary: The end of lines is rendered as a square around the last point.

member.name: T:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin
member.summary: These values determine how two joining lines are rendered in a stroker.

member.name: F:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin.Round
member.summary: Used to render rounded line joins. Circular arcs are used to join two lines smoothly.

member.name: F:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin.Bevel
member.summary: Used to render beveled line joins. The outer corner of the joined lines is filled by enclosing the triangular region of the corner with a straight line between the outer corners of each stroke.

member.name: F:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin.MiterVariable
member.summary: Used to render mitered line joins, with fixed bevels if the miter limit is exceeded. The outer edges of the strokes for the two segments are extended until they meet at an angle. If the segments meet at too sharp an angle (such that the miter would extend from the intersection of the segments a distance greater than the product of the miter limit value and the border radius), then a bevel join (see above) is used instead. This prevents long spikes being created. generates a miter line join as used in PostScript and PDF.

member.name: F:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin.Miter
member.summary: An alias for , retained for backwards compatibility.

member.name: F:SharpFont.StrokerLineJoin.MiterFixed
member.summary: Used to render mitered line joins, with variable bevels if the miter limit is exceeded. The intersection of the strokes is clipped at a line perpendicular to the bisector of the angle between the strokes, at the distance from the intersection of the segments equal to the product of the miter limit value and the border radius. This prevents long spikes being created. generates a mitered line join as used in XPS.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.Header
member.summary: A structure used to model a TrueType font header table. All fields follow the TrueType specification.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader
member.summary: A structure used to model a TrueType horizontal header, the ‘hhea’ table, as well as the corresponding horizontal metrics table, i.e., the ‘hmtx’ table.

remarks.para: IMPORTANT: The and structures should be identical except for the names of their fields which are different.
This ensures that a single function in the ‘ttload’ module is able to read both the horizontal and vertical headers.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.Version
member.summary: Gets the table version.

summary.para: Gets the font's ascender, i.e., the distance from the baseline to the top-most of all glyph points found in the font.
This value is invalid in many fonts, as it is usually set by the font designer, and often reflects only a portion of the glyphs found in the font (maybe ASCII).
You should use the ‘sTypoAscender’ field of the OS/2 table instead if you want the correct one.
Gets the font's descender, i.e., the distance from the baseline to the bottom-most of all glyph points found in the font. It is negative.
This value is invalid in many fonts, as it is usually set by the font designer, and often reflects only a portion of the glyphs found in the font (maybe ASCII).
You should use the ‘sTypoDescender’ field of the OS/2 table instead if you want the correct one.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.LineGap
member.summary: Gets the font's line gap, i.e., the distance to add to the ascender and descender to get the BTB, i.e., the baseline-to-baseline distance for the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.AdvanceWidthMax
member.summary: Gets the maximum of all advance widths found in the font. It can be used to compute the maximum width of an arbitrary string of text.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.MinimumLeftSideBearing
member.summary: Gets the minimum left side bearing of all glyphs within the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.MinimumRightSideBearing
member.summary: Gets the minimum right side bearing of all glyphs within the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.MaximumExtentX
member.summary: Gets the maximum horizontal extent (i.e., the ‘width’ of a glyph's bounding box) for all glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.CaretSlopeRise
member.summary: Gets the rise coefficient of the cursor's slope of the cursor (slope=rise/run).

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.CaretSlopeRun
member.summary: Gets the run coefficient of the cursor's slope.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.Reserved
member.summary: Gets the 8 reserved bytes.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.MetricDataFormat
member.summary: Gets 0, always.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.HMetricsCount
member.summary: Gets the number of HMetrics entries in the ‘hmtx’ table -- this value can be smaller than the total number of glyphs in the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.LongMetrics
member.summary: Gets a pointer into the ‘hmtx’ table.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.HoriHeader.ShortMetrics
member.summary: Gets a pointer into the ‘hmtx’ table.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile
member.summary: The maximum profile is a table containing many max values which can be used to pre-allocate arrays. This ensures that no memory allocation occurs during a glyph load.
member.remarks: This structure is only used during font loading.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.Version
member.summary: Gets the version number.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.GlyphCount
member.summary: Gets the number of glyphs in this TrueType font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxPoints
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of points in a non-composite TrueType glyph. See also the structure element ‘maxCompositePoints’.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxContours
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of contours in a non-composite TrueType glyph. See also the structure element ‘maxCompositeContours’.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxCompositePoints
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of points in a composite TrueType glyph. See also the structure element ‘maxPoints’.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxCompositeContours
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of contours in a composite TrueType glyph. See also the structure element ‘maxContours’.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxZones
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of zones used for glyph hinting.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxTwilightPoints
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of points in the twilight zone used for glyph hinting.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxStorage
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of elements in the storage area used for glyph hinting.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxFunctionDefs
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of function definitions in the TrueType bytecode for this font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxInstructionDefs
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of instruction definitions in the TrueType bytecode for this font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxStackElements
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of stack elements used during bytecode interpretation.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxSizeOfInstructions
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of TrueType opcodes used for glyph hinting.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxComponentElements
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of simple (i.e., non- composite) glyphs in a composite glyph.

member.name: P:SharpFont.TrueType.MaxProfile.MaxComponentDepth
member.summary: Gets the maximum nesting depth of composite glyphs.

summary.para: A structure used to model a TrueType OS/2 table. This is the long table version. All fields comply to the TrueType specification.
Note that we now support old Mac fonts which do not include an OS/2 table. In this case, the ‘version’ field is always set to 0xFFFF.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.Pclt
member.summary: A structure used to model a TrueType PCLT table. All fields comply to the TrueType specification.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId
member.summary: A list of valid values for the ‘platform_id’ identifier code in and structures.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.AppleUnicode
member.summary: Used by Apple to indicate a Unicode character map and/or name entry. See TT_APPLE_ID_XXX for corresponding ‘encoding_id’ values. Note that name entries in this format are coded as big-endian UCS-2 character codes only.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.Macintosh
member.summary: Used by Apple to indicate a MacOS-specific charmap and/or name entry. See TT_MAC_ID_XXX for corresponding ‘encoding_id’ values. Note that most TrueType fonts contain an Apple roman charmap to be usable on MacOS systems (even if they contain a Microsoft charmap as well).

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.Iso
member.summary: This value was used to specify ISO/IEC 10646 charmaps. It is however now deprecated. See TT_ISO_ID_XXX for a list of corresponding ‘encoding_id’ values.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.Microsoft
member.summary: Used by Microsoft to indicate Windows-specific charmaps. See TT_MS_ID_XXX for a list of corresponding ‘encoding_id’ values. Note that most fonts contain a Unicode charmap using (TT_PLATFORM_MICROSOFT, TT_MS_ID_UNICODE_CS).

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.Custom
member.summary: Used to indicate application-specific charmaps.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.PlatformId.Adobe
member.summary: This value isn't part of any font format specification, but is used by FreeType to report Adobe-specific charmaps in an structure. See TT_ADOBE_ID_XXX.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.EngineType
member.summary: A list of values describing which kind of TrueType bytecode engine is implemented in a given instance. It is used by the function.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.EngineType.None
member.summary: The library doesn't implement any kind of bytecode interpreter.

summary.para: The library implements a bytecode interpreter that doesn't support the patented operations of the TrueType virtual machine.
Its main use is to load certain Asian fonts which position and scale glyph components with bytecode instructions. It produces bad output for most other fonts.

member.name: F:SharpFont.TrueType.EngineType.Patented
member.summary: The library implements a bytecode interpreter that covers the full instruction set of the TrueType virtual machine (this was governed by patents until May 2010, hence the name).

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.Postscript
member.summary: A structure used to model a TrueType PostScript table. All fields comply to the TrueType specification. This structure does not reference the PostScript glyph names, which can be nevertheless accessed with the ‘ttpost’ module.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.SfntTag
member.summary: An enumeration used to specify the index of an SFNT table. Used in the API function.

member.name: T:SharpFont.TrueType.VertHeader
member.summary: A structure used to model a TrueType vertical header, the ‘vhea’ table, as well as the corresponding vertical metrics table, i.e., the ‘vmtx’ table.

remarks.para: IMPORTANT: The and structures should be identical except for the names of their fields which are different.
This ensures that a single function in the ‘ttload’ module is able to read both the horizontal and vertical headers.

You should use the ‘sTypoAscender’ field of the OS/2 table instead if you want the correct one.

member.name: T:SharpFont.Face
member.summary: FreeType root face class structure. A face object models a typeface in a font file.
member.remarks: Fields may be changed after a call to or .

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.#ctor(SharpFont.Library,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with a default faceIndex of 0.
member.param: The path of the font file.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.#ctor(SharpFont.Library,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The path of the font file.
The index of the face to take from the file.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.#ctor(SharpFont.Library,System.Byte[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class from a file that's already loaded into memory.
member.param: The index of the face to take from the file.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.#ctor(SharpFont.Library,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class from a file that's already loaded into memory.
member.param: A pointer to a buffer of a loaded file. Must not be freed before .
The index of the face to take from the file.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.#ctor(System.IntPtr,SharpFont.Library)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A pointer to the unmanaged memory containing the Face.

member.summary: Finalizes an instance of the class.

member.summary: Occurs when the face is disposed.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the object has been disposed.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.FaceCount
member.summary: Gets the number of faces in the font file. Some font formats can have multiple faces in a font file.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.FaceIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of the face in the font file. It is set to 0 if there is only one face in the font file.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.FaceFlags
member.summary: Gets a set of bit flags that give important information about the face.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.StyleFlags
member.summary: Gets a set of bit flags indicating the style of the face.

summary.para: Gets the number of glyphs in the face. If the face is scalable and has sbits (see ‘num_fixed_sizes’), it is set to the number of outline glyphs.
For CID-keyed fonts, this value gives the highest CID used in the font.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.FamilyName
member.summary: Gets the face's family name. This is an ASCII string, usually in English, which describes the typeface's family (like ‘Times New Roman’, ‘Bodoni’, ‘Garamond’, etc). This is a least common denominator used to list fonts. Some formats (TrueType & OpenType) provide localized and Unicode versions of this string. Applications should use the format specific interface to access them. Can be NULL (e.g., in fonts embedded in a PDF file).

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.StyleName
member.summary: Gets the face's style name. This is an ASCII string, usually in English, which describes the typeface's style (like ‘Italic’, ‘Bold’, ‘Condensed’, etc). Not all font formats provide a style name, so this field is optional, and can be set to NULL. As for ‘family_name’, some formats provide localized and Unicode versions of this string. Applications should use the format specific interface to access them.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.FixedSizesCount
member.summary: Gets the number of bitmap strikes in the face. Even if the face is scalable, there might still be bitmap strikes, which are called ‘sbits’ in that case.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.AvailableSizes
member.summary: Gets an array of FT_Bitmap_Size for all bitmap strikes in the face. It is set to NULL if there is no bitmap strike.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.CharmapsCount
member.summary: Gets the number of charmaps in the face.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.CharMaps
member.summary: Gets an array of the charmaps of the face.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Generic
member.summary: Gets or sets a field reserved for client uses.

summary.para: Gets the font bounding box. Coordinates are expressed in font units (see ‘units_per_EM’). The box is large enough to contain any glyph from the font. Thus, ‘bbox.yMax’ can be seen as the ‘maximal ascender’, and ‘bbox.yMin’ as the ‘minimal descender’. Only relevant for scalable formats.
Note that the bounding box might be off by (at least) one pixel for hinted fonts. See FT_Size_Metrics for further discussion.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.UnitsPerEM
member.summary: Gets the number of font units per EM square for this face. This is typically 2048 for TrueType fonts, and 1000 for Type 1 fonts. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Ascender
member.summary: Gets the typographic ascender of the face, expressed in font units. For font formats not having this information, it is set to ‘bbox.yMax’. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Descender
member.summary: Gets the typographic descender of the face, expressed in font units. For font formats not having this information, it is set to ‘bbox.yMin’.Note that this field is usually negative. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Height
member.summary: Gets the height is the vertical distance between two consecutive baselines, expressed in font units. It is always positive. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.MaxAdvanceWidth
member.summary: Gets the maximal advance width, in font units, for all glyphs in this face. This can be used to make word wrapping computations faster. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.MaxAdvanceHeight
member.summary: Gets the maximal advance height, in font units, for all glyphs in this face. This is only relevant for vertical layouts, and is set to ‘height’ for fonts that do not provide vertical metrics. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.UnderlinePosition
member.summary: Gets the position, in font units, of the underline line for this face. It is the center of the underlining stem. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.UnderlineThickness
member.summary: Gets the thickness, in font units, of the underline for this face. Only relevant for scalable formats.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Glyph
member.summary: Gets the face's associated glyph slot(s).

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Size
member.summary: Gets the current active size for this face.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.CharMap
member.summary: Gets the current active charmap for this face.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasHoriziontal
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains horizontal metrics (this is true for all font formats though).

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasVertical
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains vertical metrics.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasKerning
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains kerning data that can be accessed with .

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.IsScalable
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains a scalable font face (true for TrueType, Type 1, Type 42, CID, OpenType/CFF, and PFR font formats.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains a font whose format is based on the SFNT storage scheme. This usually means: TrueType fonts, OpenType fonts, as well as SFNT-based embedded bitmap fonts.
If this macro is true, all functions defined in FT_SFNT_NAMES_H and FT_TRUETYPE_TABLES_H are available.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.IsFixedWidth
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains a font face that contains fixed-width (or ‘monospace’, ‘fixed-pitch’, etc.) glyphs.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasFixedSizes
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains some embedded bitmaps.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasGlyphNames
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains some glyph names that can be accessed through .

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasMultipleMasters
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains some multiple masters. The functions provided by FT_MULTIPLE_MASTERS_H are then available to choose the exact design you want.

summary.para: Gets a value indicating whether a face object contains a CID-keyed font. See the discussion of FT_FACE_FLAG_CID_KEYED for more details.
If this macro is true, all functions defined in FT_CID_H are available.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.IsTricky
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a face represents a ‘tricky’ font. See the discussion of FT_FACE_FLAG_TRICKY for more details.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.HasColor
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the font has color glyph tables.

member.name: P:SharpFont.Face.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets an object used to identify this instance of . This object will not be modified or accessed internally.
member.remarks: This is a replacement for FT_Generic in FreeType. If you are retrieving the same object multiple times from functions, this object will not appear in new copies.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.CheckTrueTypePatents

summary.para: Parse all bytecode instructions of a TrueType font file to check whether any of the patented opcodes are used. This is only useful if you want to be able to use the unpatented hinter with fonts that do not use these opcodes.
Note that this function parses all glyph instructions in the font file, which may be slow.

member.remarks: Since May 2010, TrueType hinting is no longer patented.
member.returns: True if this is a TrueType font that uses one of the patented opcodes, false otherwise.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.SetUnpatentedHinting(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enable or disable the unpatented hinter for a given . Only enable it if you have determined that the face doesn't use any patented opcodes.
member.remarks: Since May 2010, TrueType hinting is no longer patented.
member.returns: The old setting value. This will always be false if this is not an SFNT font, or if the unpatented hinter is not compiled in this instance of the library.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.AttachFile(System.String)

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.AttachStream(SharpFont.OpenArgs)
member.summary: ‘Attach’ data to a face object. Normally, this is used to read additional information for the face object. For example, you can attach an AFM file that comes with a Type 1 font to get the kerning values and other metrics.

remarks.para: The meaning of the ‘attach’ (i.e., what really happens when the new file is read) is not fixed by FreeType itself. It really depends on the font format (and thus the font driver).
Client applications are expected to know what they are doing when invoking this function. Most drivers simply do not implement file attachments.

member.param: A pointer to which must be filled by the caller.

member.summary: This function calls to request the nominal size (in points).

remarks.para: If either the character width or height is zero, it is set equal to the other value.
If either the horizontal or vertical resolution is zero, it is set equal to the other value.
A character width or height smaller than 1pt is set to 1pt; if both resolution values are zero, they are set to 72dpi.

For subsetted CID-keyed fonts, is returned for invalid CID values (this is, for CID values which don't have a corresponding glyph in the font). See the discussion of the flag for more details.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.SetTransform(SharpFont.FTMatrix,SharpFont.FTVector)
member.summary: A function used to set the transformation that is applied to glyph images when they are loaded into a glyph slot through .

remarks.para: The transformation is only applied to scalable image formats after the glyph has been loaded. It means that hinting is unaltered by the transformation and is performed on the character size given in the last call to or .
Note that this also transforms the ‘face.glyph.advance’ field, but not the values in ‘face.glyph.metrics’.

member.param: A pointer to the transformation's 2x2 matrix. Use the method overloads for the identity matrix.
A pointer to the translation vector. Use the method overloads for the null vector.

member.summary: A function used to set the transformation that is applied to glyph images when they are loaded into a glyph slot through with the identity matrix.

remarks.para: The transformation is only applied to scalable image formats after the glyph has been loaded. It means that hinting is unaltered by the transformation and is performed on the character size given in the last call to or .
Note that this also transforms the ‘face.glyph.advance’ field, but not the values in ‘face.glyph.metrics’.

member.param: A pointer to the translation vector. Use the method overloads for the null vector.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.SetTransform(SharpFont.FTMatrix)
member.summary: A function used to set the transformation that is applied to glyph images when they are loaded into a glyph slot through with the null vector.

remarks.para: The transformation is only applied to scalable image formats after the glyph has been loaded. It means that hinting is unaltered by the transformation and is performed on the character size given in the last call to or .
Note that this also transforms the ‘face.glyph.advance’ field, but not the values in ‘face.glyph.metrics’.

member.param: A pointer to the transformation's 2x2 matrix. Use the method overloads for the identity matrix.

member.summary: Return the kerning vector between two glyphs of a same face.
member.remarks: Only horizontal layouts (left-to-right & right-to-left) are supported by this method. Other layouts, or more sophisticated kernings, are out of the scope of this API function -- they can be implemented through format-specific interfaces.

The index of the right glyph in the kern pair.
Determines the scale and dimension of the returned kerning vector.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetGlyphName(System.UInt32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieve the ASCII name of a given glyph in a face. This only works for those faces where returns 1.

remarks.para: An error is returned if the face doesn't provide glyph names or if the glyph index is invalid. In all cases of failure, the first byte of ‘buffer’ is set to 0 to indicate an empty name.
The glyph name is truncated to fit within the buffer if it is too long. The returned string is always zero-terminated.
Be aware that FreeType reorders glyph indices internally so that glyph index 0 always corresponds to the ‘missing glyph’ (called ‘.notdef’).
This function is not compiled within the library if the config macro ‘FT_CONFIG_OPTION_NO_GLYPH_NAMES’ is defined in ‘include/freetype/config/ftoptions.h’.

member.param: The maximal number of bytes available in the buffer.
member.returns: The ASCII name of a given glyph in a face.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetGlyphName(System.UInt32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Retrieve the ASCII name of a given glyph in a face. This only works for those faces where returns 1.

remarks.para: An error is returned if the face doesn't provide glyph names or if the glyph index is invalid. In all cases of failure, the first byte of ‘buffer’ is set to 0 to indicate an empty name.
The glyph name is truncated to fit within the buffer if it is too long. The returned string is always zero-terminated.
Be aware that FreeType reorders glyph indices internally so that glyph index 0 always corresponds to the ‘missing glyph’ (called ‘.notdef’).
This function is not compiled within the library if the config macro ‘FT_CONFIG_OPTION_NO_GLYPH_NAMES’ is defined in ‘include/freetype/config/ftoptions.h’.

member.param: The target buffer where the name is copied to.
member.returns: The ASCII name of a given glyph in a face.

member.summary: Retrieve the ASCII Postscript name of a given face, if available. This only works with Postscript and TrueType fonts.
member.remarks: The returned pointer is owned by the face and is destroyed with it.
member.returns: A pointer to the face's Postscript name. NULL if unavailable.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.SelectCharmap(SharpFont.Encoding)
member.summary: Select a given charmap by its encoding tag (as listed in ‘freetype.h’).

remarks.para: This function returns an error if no charmap in the face corresponds to the encoding queried here.
Because many fonts contain more than a single cmap for Unicode encoding, this function has some special code to select the one which covers Unicode best. It is thus preferable to in this case.

member.param: A handle to the selected encoding.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.SetCharmap(SharpFont.CharMap)
member.summary: Select a given charmap for character code to glyph index mapping.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetCharIndex(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Return the glyph index of a given character code. This function uses a charmap object to do the mapping.
member.remarks: If you use FreeType to manipulate the contents of font files directly, be aware that the glyph index returned by this function doesn't always correspond to the internal indices used within the file. This is done to ensure that value 0 always corresponds to the ‘missing glyph’.
member.returns: The glyph index. 0 means ‘undefined character code’.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetFirstChar(System.UInt32@)
member.summary: This function is used to return the first character code in the current charmap of a given face. It also returns the corresponding glyph index.

remarks.para: You should use this function with to be able to parse all character codes available in a given charmap.
Note that ‘agindex’ is set to 0 if the charmap is empty. The result itself can be 0 in two cases: if the charmap is empty or when the value 0 is the first valid character code.

member.param: Glyph index of first character code. 0 if charmap is empty.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetNextChar(System.UInt32,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: This function is used to return the next character code in the current charmap of a given face following the value ‘charCode’, as well as the corresponding glyph index.

remarks.para: You should use this function with to walk over all character codes available in a given charmap. See the note for this function for a simple code example.
Note that ‘*agindex’ is set to 0 when there are no more codes in the charmap.

member.param: Glyph index of first character code. 0 if charmap is empty.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetNameIndex(System.String)

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetPSFontValue(SharpFont.PostScript.DictionaryKeys,System.UInt32,System.IntPtr@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieve the value for the supplied key from a PostScript font.

remarks.para: The values returned are not pointers into the internal structures of the face, but are ‘fresh’ copies, so that the memory containing them belongs to the calling application. This also enforces the ‘read-only’ nature of these values, i.e., this function cannot be used to manipulate the face.
‘value’ is a void pointer because the values returned can be of various types.
If either ‘value’ is NULL or ‘value_len’ is too small, just the required memory size for the requested entry is returned.

The ‘idx’ parameter is used, not only to retrieve elements of, for example, the FontMatrix or FontBBox, but also to retrieve name keys from the CharStrings dictionary, and the charstrings themselves. It is ignored for atomic values.
returns a value that is scaled up by 1000. To get the value as in the font stream, you need to divide by 65536000.0 (to remove the FT_Fixed scale, and the x1000 scale).

IMPORTANT: Only key/value pairs read by the FreeType interpreter can be retrieved. So, for example, PostScript procedures such as NP, ND, and RD are not available. Arbitrary keys are, obviously, not be available either.
If the font's format is not PostScript-based, this function returns the error code.

member.param: An enumeration value representing the dictionary key to retrieve.
For array values, this specifies the index to be returned.
A pointer to memory into which to write the value.
The size, in bytes, of the memory supplied for the value.
member.returns: The amount of memory (in bytes) required to hold the requested value (if it exists, -1 otherwise).

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetBdfCharsetId(System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: Retrieve a BDF font character set identity, according to the BDF specification.

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetBdfProperty(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieve a BDF property from a BDF or PCF font file.

remarks.para: This function works with BDF and PCF fonts. It returns an error otherwise. It also returns an error if the property is not in the font.
A ‘property’ is a either key-value pair within the STARTPROPERTIES ... ENDPROPERTIES block of a BDF font or a key-value pair from the ‘info->props’ array within a ‘FontRec’ structure of a PCF font.
Integer properties are always stored as ‘signed’ within PCF fonts; consequently, is a possible return value for BDF fonts only.
In case of error, ‘aproperty->type’ is always set to .

member.name: M:SharpFont.Face.GetCidRegistryOrderingSupplement(System.String@,System.String@,System.Int32@)

member.summary: Validate various OpenType tables to assure that all offsets and indices are valid. The idea is that a higher-level library which actually does the text layout can access those tables without error checking (which can be quite time consuming).

After use, the application should deallocate the five tables with . A NULL value indicates that the table either doesn't exist in the font, or the application hasn't asked for validation.

A pointer to the BASE table.
A pointer to the GDEF table.
A pointer to the GPOS table.
A pointer to the GSUB table.

member.name: T:SharpFont.FaceFlags
member.summary: A list of bit flags used in the ‘face_flags’ field of the structure. They inform client applications of properties of the corresponding face.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.None
member.summary: No style flags.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Scalable
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains outline glyphs. This doesn't prevent bitmap strikes, i.e., a face can have both this and and set.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.FixedSizes
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains bitmap strikes. See also and .

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.FixedWidth
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains fixed-width characters (like Courier, Lucido, MonoType, etc.).

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Sfnt
member.summary: Indicates that the face uses the ‘sfnt’ storage scheme. For now, this means TrueType and OpenType.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Horizontal
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains horizontal glyph metrics. This should be set for all common formats.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Vertical
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains vertical glyph metrics. This is only available in some formats, not all of them.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Kerning
member.summary: Indicates that the face contains kerning information. If set, the kerning distance can be retrieved through the function . Otherwise the function always return the vector (0,0). Note that FreeType doesn't handle kerning data from the ‘GPOS’ table (as present in some OpenType fonts).

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.FastGlyphs
member.summary: THIS FLAG IS DEPRECATED. DO NOT USE OR TEST IT.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.MultipleMasters
member.summary: Indicates that the font contains multiple masters and is capable of interpolating between them. See the multiple-masters specific API for details.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.GlyphNames
member.summary: Indicates that the font contains glyph names that can be retrieved through . Note that some TrueType fonts contain broken glyph name tables. Use the function when needed.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.ExternalStream
member.summary: Used internally by FreeType to indicate that a face's stream was provided by the client application and should not be destroyed when is called. Don't read or test this flag.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Hinter
member.summary: Set if the font driver has a hinting machine of its own. For example, with TrueType fonts, it makes sense to use data from the SFNT ‘gasp’ table only if the native TrueType hinting engine (with the bytecode interpreter) is available and active.

summary.para: Set if the font is CID-keyed. In that case, the font is not accessed by glyph indices but by CID values. For subsetted CID-keyed fonts this has the consequence that not all index values are a valid argument to . Only the CID values for which corresponding glyphs in the subsetted font exist make return successfully; in all other cases you get an error.

Note that CID-keyed fonts which are in an SFNT wrapper don't have this flag set since the glyphs are accessed in the normal way (using contiguous indices); the ‘CID-ness’ isn't visible to the application.

Set if the font is ‘tricky’, this is, it always needs the font format's native hinting engine to get a reasonable result. A typical example is the Chinese font ‘mingli.ttf’ which uses TrueType bytecode instructions to move and scale all of its subglyphs.
It is not possible to autohint such fonts using ; it will also ignore . You have to set both and to really disable hinting; however, you probably never want this except for demonstration purposes.
Currently, there are about a dozen TrueType fonts in the list of tricky fonts; they are hard-coded in file ‘ttobjs.c’.

member.name: F:SharpFont.FaceFlags.Color
member.summary: Set if the font has color glyph tables. To access color glyphs use .

member.name: T:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes
member.summary: A list of bit flags used in the ‘fsType’ field of the OS/2 table in a TrueType or OpenType font and the ‘FSType’ entry in a PostScript font. These bit flags are returned by FT_Get_FSType_Flags; they inform client applications of embedding and subsetting restrictions associated with a font.
member.remarks: While the fsType flags can indicate that a font may be embedded, a license with the font vendor may be separately required to use the font in this way.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.Installable
member.summary: Fonts with no fsType bit set may be embedded and permanently installed on the remote system by an application.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.RestrictedLicense
member.summary: Fonts that have only this bit set must not be modified, embedded or exchanged in any manner without first obtaining permission of the font software copyright owner.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.PreviewAndPrint
member.summary: If this bit is set, the font may be embedded and temporarily loaded on the remote system. Documents containing Preview & Print fonts must be opened ‘read-only’; no edits can be applied to the document.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.Editable
member.summary: If this bit is set, the font may be embedded but must only be installed temporarily on other systems. In contrast to Preview & Print fonts, documents containing editable fonts may be opened for reading, editing is permitted, and changes may be saved.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.NoSubsetting
member.summary: If this bit is set, the font may not be subsetted prior to embedding.

member.name: F:SharpFont.EmbeddingTypes.BitmapOnly
member.summary: If this bit is set, only bitmaps contained in the font may be embedded; no outline data may be embedded. If there are no bitmaps available in the font, then the font is unembeddable.

member.summary: Miscellaneous FreeType2 functions that don't fit anywhere else.
member.content: This file contains all the raw FreeType2 function signatures.

member.name: M:SharpFont.FT.MulDiv(SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)

summary.para: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*b)/c’ with maximal accuracy (it uses a 64-bit intermediate integer whenever necessary).
This function isn't necessarily as fast as some processor specific operations, but is at least completely portable.

member.returns: The result of ‘(a*b)/c’. This function never traps when trying to divide by zero; it simply returns ‘MaxInt’ or ‘MinInt’ depending on the signs of ‘a’ and ‘b’.

member.name: M:SharpFont.FT.MulFix(System.Int32,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)
member.summary: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*b)/0x10000’ with maximal accuracy. Most of the time this is used to multiply a given value by a 16.16 fixed float factor.

remarks.para: This function has been optimized for the case where the absolute value of ‘a’ is less than 2048, and ‘b’ is a 16.16 scaling factor. As this happens mainly when scaling from notional units to fractional pixels in FreeType, it resulted in noticeable speed improvements between versions 2.x and 1.x.
As a conclusion, always try to place a 16.16 factor as the second argument of this function; this can make a great difference.

member.param: The second multiplier. Use a 16.16 factor here whenever possible (see note below).

member.name: M:SharpFont.FT.DivFix(System.Int32,SharpFont.Fixed16Dot16)
member.summary: A very simple function used to perform the computation ‘(a*0x10000)/b’ with maximal accuracy. Most of the time, this is used to divide a given value by a 16.16 fixed float factor.
member.remarks: The optimization for is simple: If (a << 16) fits in 32 bits, then the division is computed directly. Otherwise, we use a specialized version of .
member.param: The second multiplier. Use a 16.16 factor here whenever possible (see note below).

member.name: T:SharpFont.GenericFinalizer
member.summary: Describe a function used to destroy the ‘client’ data of any FreeType object. See the description of the type for details of usage.
member.param: The address of the FreeType object which is under finalization. Its client data is accessed through its ‘generic’ field.

summary.para: Client applications often need to associate their own data to a variety of FreeType core objects. For example, a text layout API might want to associate a glyph cache to a given size object.
Most FreeType object contains a ‘generic’ field, of type , which usage is left to client applications and font servers.

It can be used to store a pointer to client-specific data, as well as the address of a ‘finalizer’ function, which will be called by FreeType when the object is destroyed (for example, the previous client example would put the address of the glyph cache destructor in the ‘finalizer’ field).

member.name: M:SharpFont.Glyph.GetCBox(SharpFont.GlyphBBoxMode)

summary.para: Return a glyph's ‘control box’. The control box encloses all the outline's points, including Bézier control points. Though it coincides with the exact bounding box for most glyphs, it can be slightly larger in some situations (like when rotating an outline which contains Bézier outside arcs).

Computing the control box is very fast, while getting the bounding box can take much more time as it needs to walk over all segments and arcs in the outline. To get the latter, you can use the ‘ftbbox’ component which is dedicated to this single task.

remarks.para: Coordinates are relative to the glyph origin, using the y upwards convention.
If the glyph has been loaded with , ‘bbox_mode’ must be set to to get unscaled font units in 26.6 pixel format. The value is another name for this constant.

If the font is tricky and the glyph has been loaded with , the resulting CBox is meaningless. To get reasonable values for the CBox it is necessary to load the glyph at a large ppem value (so that the hinting instructions can properly shift and scale the subglyphs), then extracting the CBox which can be eventually converted back to font units.
Note that the maximum coordinates are exclusive, which means that one can compute the width and height of the glyph image (be it in integer or 26.6 pixels) as:

para.code: width = bbox.xMax - bbox.xMin; height = bbox.yMax - bbox.yMin;

remarks.para: Note also that for 26.6 coordinates, if ‘bbox_mode’ is set to , the coordinates will also be grid-fitted, which corresponds to:
To get the bbox in pixel coordinates, set ‘bbox_mode’ to .
To get the bbox in grid-fitted pixel coordinates, set ‘bbox_mode’ to .

member.param: The mode which indicates how to interpret the returned bounding box values.
member.returns: The glyph coordinate bounding box. Coordinates are expressed in 1/64th of pixels if it is grid-fitted.

The glyph image is translated with the ‘origin’ vector before rendering.

A pointer to a vector used to translate the glyph image before rendering. Can be 0 (if no translation). The origin is expressed in 26.6 pixels.
